articles.title: Being together brings us closer to our girls, say Southport families
articles.summary: Parents of Alice, Bebe and Elsie tell BBC documentary they have supported each other through grief.
articles.content:
Being together brings us closer to our girls, say Southport families

4 hours ago Share Save Sarah Campbell, Claire Ryan and George Sandeman Share Save

Watch: Home videos give a personal glimpse into the lives of Alice, Bebe and Elsie

The families of three girls killed at a dance class in Southport last year say spending time together has helped them through their grief. A small team of journalists from BBC Breakfast have been following the families for the last nine months as part of a documentary to be shown on BBC One on Tuesday. In it, they reveal how they have grieved for their daughters and set up legacy projects in their names. "We've been together in some of the most difficult conversations," says Jenni Stancombe, mum of Elsie. "But together, between the six of us, we always seem to pull the light out [of the darkness]." Elsie, aged seven, Alice da Silva Aguiar, nine, and Bebe King, six, died at a Taylor Swift-themed dance workshop in July 2024.

The Southport families at a primary school where money they raised has built a new playground

Over nine months the BBC recorded deeply personal interviews with the girls' parents, who have for the first time shared family footage of their daughters. The programme follows how the three families set out to create lasting legacies in their girls' names. It shows how they trained for and competed in the London Marathon as well as the opening of a new playground at the school attended by two of the girls. The families didn't know each other before the tragedy, but Lauren King, mum of Bebe, says meeting up since they died has been "crucial to our survival" and a "blessing". "We can talk about our girls, the similarities," she says, reflecting on the girls' shared love of dance and performing. "I feel more close to Alice when I'm with them," says Alice's mum Alexandra Aguiar. "I feel more connected to the girls." Mrs Stancombe adds: "I'll never forget Alex coming to say to me that Alice is a real mother figure and she'll be mothering [Elsie and Bebe], wherever they are. She was like, 'I promise you she'll be looking after them.'"

Family handouts The parents of Elsie, Alice and Bebe have realised how similar they were when sharing memories of them

The documentary includes home videos of the girls talking and laughing. In one, Elsie says: "You don't need to buy a smile, you just bring up your face." Using Elsie's attitude to cartwheeling as an example, her dad David Stancombe adds: "When she was focused on something, she was determined to master it." In another clip, while filming herself, Alice says: "Hello, it's me!" Describing his daughter, Sergio Aguiar tells us that Alice did not walk anywhere, "she danced". One clip of Bebe shows her messing around at home in an oversized hat while wearing a backpack. She lit up every room she entered, her parents say. "She was totally selfless," adds her dad Ben King. The families also describe how much their girls were looking forward to the dance workshop before they died. "I saw [the class] and booked it as a surprise," says Mrs King. "Alice knew all the songs, she was singing and dancing [to them]," says Mrs Aguiar. "That class, to be Taylor Swift-themed, was the reason [Elsie] went," Mrs Stancombe adds. "She only went to dance and make bracelets; and she never came home."

The families say they have been of great support to each other while grieving for their girls

Mr and Mrs Stancombe tell the BBC of the shared pain they felt when meeting the Aguiar and King families for the first time. "When I first met them, I felt their pain for them. It hurts us [to know]," Mrs Stancombe says - her voice trailing off - "what they're going through," her husband adds. "Although we'd have liked not to have met under these circumstances, we are very happy that we have," says Mrs King. "We try to support each other," says Mr Aguiar. His wife agrees: "We are all different but we are very special to each other." The legacy projects established for each of the girls include Alice's WonderDance, made by the Aguiars to support young performers with uniforms, classes and transport. The Stancombes have created Elsie's Story, a charitable trust that makes grants to assist young people and support others in the Southport area. One of the projects they have helped fund is Bebe's Hive, a creative centre set up by the Kings that offers support to grieving children. Mr King says: "I think when we get together, something just takes over - like we're protected." His wife adds: "We've got each other through, we've gained family".
articles.reasoning: The article describes how families affected by a tragic loss have come together to support each other through grief and have created meaningful legacy projects that benefit their community, including support for young performers and grieving children. This represents a positive real-world impact with broad significance and substantial substance focused on healing and community resilience.
articles.personality_title: Southport families unite to honor daughters and support community after tragedy
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Last year, three young girls named Elsie, Alice, and Bebe died at a dance class in Southport. Their families, who did not know each other before, have come together to cope with their loss.

**What happened** – Over nine months, the BBC followed the families as they shared their grief and memories. They showed home videos of the girls and talked about how they bonded. The families also worked together on projects to remember the girls, like building a new playground and creating support groups for young performers and grieving children.

**Impact** – These families found comfort in each other’s company and turned their sadness into positive actions. By creating legacy projects, they help other children in their community, keeping their daughters’ memories alive in meaningful ways. Their teamwork shows how people can find strength and hope even after difficult times.

**What’s next step** – The families will continue running their projects like Alice’s WonderDance, Elsie’s Story, and Bebe’s Hive. These groups will offer support and opportunities for local children, helping them grow and heal.

**One-sentence takeaway** – After losing their daughters, Southport families joined forces to support each other and create lasting community projects that help children heal and thrive.

articles.title: Scientists reveal a surprising new timeline for ancient Egypt
articles.summary: A new radiocarbon study has clarified the timing of the colossal Thera eruption, placing it before Egypt’s New Kingdom. Researchers analyzed artifacts tied to Pharaoh Ahmose, gaining rare access to museum materials. Their results favor a younger chronology for early 18th Dynasty Egypt. The revised timeline reshapes regional historical connections.
articles.content:
One of the most powerful volcanic events of the past 10,000 years occurred on the Greek island of Thera (Santorini) in the Aegean Sea, yet researchers have long debated whether it took place in the late 17th or 16th century BCE. Ash from the eruption spread across much of the eastern Mediterranean, prompting archaeologists to question how this dramatic event aligned with ancient Egyptian chronology. A research team from Ben-Gurion University of the Negev and the University of Groningen has now provided the first radiocarbon dates related to King Ahmose, the ruler known for reunifying Upper and Lower Egypt and founding the New Kingdom. Their results suggest that the Santorini eruption happened before the New Kingdom, placing it in the Second Intermediate Period. These new measurements strongly support a "low" (i.e. younger) timeline for the start of the 18th Dynasty, a shift that reshapes our understanding of Egypt’s interactions with nearby cultures.

Their findings were published in PLOS One.

New Radiocarbon Sampling From Key Egyptian Artifacts

Prof. Hendrik J. Bruins of the Jacob Blaustein Institutes for Desert Research at BGU's Sylan Adams Sde Boker Campus and Prof. Johannes van der Plicht of the University of Groningen received exceptional access to select artifacts from the British Museum and the Petrie Museum in London. Under the supervision of museum teams, they collected samples from several objects for radiocarbon dating. These included a mudbrick from the Ahmose Temple at Abydos (British Museum), a linen burial cloth linked to Satdjehuty (British Museum), and six wooden stick shabtis from Thebes (Petrie Museum).

Revised Timeline for the Santorini Eruption and Early Dynasties

Analysis of the samples showed that the massive eruption did not take place during the Egyptian New Kingdom, as some earlier interpretations suggested. Instead, it occurred earlier in the Second Intermediate Period. The radiocarbon ages for the Santorini event were markedly older than the first radiocarbon dates obtained for artifacts associated with Pharaoh Ahmose and those from the 17th to early 18th Dynasty.

"Our findings indicate that the Second Intermediate Period lasted considerably longer than traditional assessments, and the New Kingdom started later," says Prof. Hendrik J. Bruins.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific breakthrough in understanding ancient history through new radiocarbon dating, which reshapes the timeline of a major volcanic event and ancient Egyptian chronology. This has broad cultural and historical significance, providing new insights into regional interactions and historical periods, benefiting the general public's knowledge of human history.
articles.personality_title: New study changes timeline of ancient Egypt and Santorini eruption
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists have long debated when the huge volcanic eruption on the Greek island of Thera (also called Santorini) happened. This eruption spread ash across the eastern Mediterranean and might be linked to important periods in ancient Egyptian history.

**What happened** – Researchers from Ben-Gurion University and the University of Groningen studied artifacts connected to Pharaoh Ahmose, who started Egypt’s New Kingdom. They got special permission to test objects from the British and Petrie Museums using radiocarbon dating. Their results show the Santorini eruption happened before the New Kingdom, during an earlier time called the Second Intermediate Period.

**Impact** – This study changes the timeline for both the eruption and early Egyptian history. It means the Second Intermediate Period lasted longer, and the New Kingdom began later than previously thought. This helps historians better understand how Egypt and nearby cultures interacted.

**What's next step** – The new timeline may lead to more research about ancient events in the eastern Mediterranean. Scientists will likely study other artifacts to confirm these dates and explore how this changes the story of ancient civilizations.

**One-sentence takeaway** – New radiocarbon tests show the Santorini eruption happened before Egypt’s New Kingdom, revising ancient history timelines in the region.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une nouvelle étude modifie la chronologie de l'Égypte ancienne et de l'éruption de Santorin
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques ont longtemps débattu de la date de la grande éruption volcanique sur l'île grecque de Théra (appelée aussi Santorin). Cette éruption a répandu des cendres dans tout l'est de la Méditerranée et pourrait être liée à des périodes importantes de l'histoire égyptienne ancienne.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des chercheurs de l'Université Ben-Gourion et de l'Université de Groningen ont étudié des objets liés au pharaon Ahmose, fondateur du Nouvel Empire égyptien. Ils ont obtenu une autorisation spéciale pour dater ces objets dans les musées de Londres grâce à la datation au radiocarbone. Leurs résultats montrent que l'éruption de Santorin a eu lieu avant le Nouvel Empire, durant une période plus ancienne appelée le Deuxième Période Intermédiaire.

**Impact** – Cette étude modifie la chronologie de l'éruption et de l'histoire égyptienne ancienne. Cela signifie que le Deuxième Période Intermédiaire a duré plus longtemps et que le Nouvel Empire a commencé plus tard que ce que l'on pensait. Cela aide les historiens à mieux comprendre les interactions entre l'Égypte et les cultures voisines.

**Étape suivante** – Cette nouvelle chronologie pourrait conduire à d'autres recherches sur les événements anciens en Méditerranée orientale. Les scientifiques vont probablement étudier d'autres objets pour confirmer ces dates et explorer comment cela change l'histoire des civilisations anciennes.

**Résumé en une phrase** – De nouveaux tests au radiocarbone montrent que l'éruption de Santorin a eu lieu avant le Nouvel Empire égyptien, révisant les chronologies de l'histoire ancienne dans la région.
articles.personality_title_es: Nuevo estudio cambia la cronología del antiguo Egipto y la erupción de Santorini
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Durante mucho tiempo, los científicos han debatido cuándo ocurrió la gran erupción volcánica en la isla griega de Thera (también llamada Santorini). Esta erupción esparció ceniza por el este del Mediterráneo y podría estar relacionada con períodos importantes de la historia del antiguo Egipto.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de la Universidad Ben-Gurión y la Universidad de Groningen estudiaron artefactos vinculados al faraón Ahmose, quien fundó el Nuevo Reino de Egipto. Obtuvieron permiso especial para hacer pruebas de datación por radiocarbono en objetos de los museos británico y Petrie. Sus resultados muestran que la erupción de Santorini ocurrió antes del Nuevo Reino, durante un periodo anterior llamado Segundo Período Intermedio.

**Impacto** – Este estudio cambia la cronología tanto de la erupción como de la historia temprana de Egipto. Significa que el Segundo Período Intermedio duró más tiempo y que el Nuevo Reino comenzó más tarde de lo que se pensaba. Esto ayuda a los historiadores a entender mejor cómo Egipto interactuaba con culturas cercanas.

**Próximos pasos** – La nueva cronología puede llevar a más investigaciones sobre eventos antiguos en el Mediterráneo oriental. Los científicos probablemente estudiarán más artefactos para confirmar estas fechas y explorar cómo cambia la historia de las civilizaciones antiguas.

**Resumen en una frase** – Nuevas pruebas de radiocarbono muestran que la erupción de Santorini ocurrió antes del Nuevo Reino de Egipto, revisando las cronologías históricas en la región.
